Award.AwardTitle: The Particle Physics and Cosmology of Supersymmetry and String Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
For the past two decades, string theory has been one of the most intensely investigated areas of theoretical high-energy physics. This is true chiefly because string theory offers what is currently the most successful method of unifying gravity with the other fundamental forces (strong, weak, and electromagnetic). In this project, Professor Ovrut and his collaborators seek to create an international and interdisciplinary research group that will formulate a wide class of realistic string models, and, within this context, calculate fundamental properties of particle physics and cosmology. Among the physics goals is to predict the mass spectrum of the new supersymmetric particles, explore possible new physics just above the electroweak scale, numerically compute Yukawa couplings, explore the implications of these theories for cosmology, and confront these theories with the data from the LHC and cosmological observations.

This project is also envisioned to have considerable broader impacts. Primary among these is the synergy of bringing together representatives of three disciplines (string theory, mathematics, and cosmology) in three different countries to solve some of the most fundamental problems in modern science. This work could therefore become a vehicle for enhancing American and European scientific cooperation, as well as a concrete mechanism to train post-doctoral associates and graduate students in a multinational educational environment. In particular, this work will give American and European students and post-doctoral associates unparalleled opportunities to study, conduct research and attend specialized courses, workshops, conferences and schools organized at our participating universities, Centers, Institute and Laboratory. There is also significant outreach potential by communicating the content of the research to interested non-scientists through public lectures and the media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The international research program entitled "The Particle Physics and Cosmology of Supersymmetry and String Theory"  was a collaboration of six major academic institutions -- the University of Pennsylvania and Princeton in the United States, Oxford University and Imperial College in the United Kingdom and the University of Hamburg/DESY and the Ludwig Maximillians University/Max Planck Institute for Physics in Germany. The program has been supported for the past four years by three correlated research grants from the NSF in the USA, the DFG in Germany and EPSRC in the UK respectively, which fund the research efforts of nine principal investigators--three in each country--as well as a number of their collaborative colleagues. The international program tackles some of the most fundamental problems in particle physics and cosmology. These subjects have different emphasis in each of the three countries, and the program was specifically designed to facilitate international and interdisciplinary collaboration to exploit these differing viewpoints. 

 

The project obtained detailed  insights into the fundamental forces and constituents of matter under conditions that existed in the very early universe, only billionth of seconds after the Big Bang, when the foundations for the evolution and actual structure of our universe were determined. Remarkable progress was made in exploring the interactions of the elementary particles and in understanding the evolution of the universe--at short distances or, equivalently, at very high energies. Both in Low-energy particle physics and cosmology are well-described by the ``standard model'' of elementary particles and the ``concordance model'' respectively. On the conceptual level, the SM is based on the framework of local quantum field theory, whereas the CM is built upon general relativity as the classical theory for gravity. Although the SM and the CM have been experimentally confirmed to a high level of accuracy, both suffer from serious theoretical problems whose lack of understanding signal the need to extend them into the high-energy, new physics in the ultraviolet (UV) regime beyond the standard paradigms. This research project addressed many of these theoretical problems directly--within the context of supersymmetry and  superstring theory--and made substantial progress. For example, although the SM is successful in describing the spectrum and interactions of the elementary particles, all parameters in the theory, such as the particle masses and the gauge coupling parameters, must be inserted by hand--without any understanding of how they attain these values. Another unexplained issue is the ``hierarchy problem''; that is, why is the gravitational force so much weaker than all the other gauge forces? Even deeper issues concern gravitation. General relativity is a classical theory, given in terms of a geometrical description of curved space-time. One of the most pressing questions in theoretical physics is--how can a quantum theory of gravity be formulated? Superstrings and M/F-theory -- and the associated low energy supergravity theories -- are currently the best candidates for an ultraviolet framework consistent with both low energy particle physics and cosmology.  Although these theories have been extensively investigated in recent years, the study of string vacua, intrinsically stringy geometries, their mathematical structures and implications for particle physics and cosmology remained cutting edge problems in both theoretical physics and mathematics.  This project made enormous progress in addressing some of these fundamental mathematical and physical issues.
